Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution in Mexico; contradictions in testimony; lacked evidence; moved internally but did not seek local protection or prove inability to relocate safely
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging credibility and internal flight alternative findings
Evidence_Used: Panel's assessment of internal relocation options
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony
Lack of supporting documentation
Failure to demonstrate inability to access protection internally
Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Decision_Outcome: Asylum claim dismissed by Refugee Protection Division
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Panel's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for factual findings
Correctness standard for jurisdictional issues
Decision_Rationale: Findings on credibility and internal flight alternative were reasonable based on record and applicable law

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving document authenticity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration and Refugee Board's decision was unreasonable due to bias or errors in evidence evaluation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in applicant's story, use of forged passport, lack of credibility
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis for refugee claim
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Significant inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived bias and errors in evidence evaluation by the Board
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law and immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed persecution and sought refugee status
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act regarding false documents and refugee eligibility
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving allegations of misrepresentation and bias
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal's decision was unreasonable due to bias or flawed evidence assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to contradictions and implausibilities
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA on misrepresentation in immigration applications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility and consistency of applicant's narrative
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative tribunal proceeding followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistencies and implausible elements in refugee claim
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by reviewing court
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; court found Board considered relevant evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness and absence of apprehension of bias
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of forged documents and inconsistent statements
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of forged passport in support of claim

Application_Facts: The applicant faced abuse but did not pursue higher authorities or file complaints during a stay with her aunt. Evidence showed Mexico makes efforts to protect citizens, though local police were ineffective due to familial influence.
Claimant_Status: Applicant claiming refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed the RPD's decision under the reasonableness standard without substituting the court's opinion.
Evidence_Used: Evidence showed Mexico makes efforts to protect citizens, though local police were ineffective due to familial influence.
Decision_Outcome: The RPD's decision was reasonable and supported by evidence.
Outcome: The judicial review application was dismissed, upholding the RPD's original decision.
Legal_Standard_Applied: The claimant must prove no evidence supports the RPD's decision.
Decision_Rationale: The RPD concluded that Mexican authorities could provide protection to the applicant, and this conclusion was found to be reasonable based on available evidence.

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual claiming persecution as a victim of sexual assault
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator's power and influence, fear of retaliation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Serious possibility of harm if returned
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible but not sufficient to meet burden
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not fully established under legal standards
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 96, s. 97

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perceived inability to access state protection
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Alleged serious risk to life or safety
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted threat due to prior assault
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove jeopardy throughout country
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Findings supported by reasonableness standard
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 96, s. 97

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on state complicity or failure
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to corruption and lack of accountability
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, domestic immigration law
Crimes.Credibility: Not sufficient to rebut presumption of state protection

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant did not seek federal protection in Mexico
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Burden of proof on applicant for IFA and state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian Federal Court review of RPD decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide evidence of unsafe conditions nationwide
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable findings by Board
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for state protection; patent unreasonableness for IFA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to prove lack of state protection or unreasonable hardship in relocation
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Immigration and Refugee Board

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that the Applicant had a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Kiev
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Credibility_Assessment: The Applicant's claims of anti-Semitic persecution were not fully credible; issues found to be localized and personal in nature
Evidence_Type: Evidence regarding localized threats, state protection in Kiev, resource limitations affecting all citizens, personal vendetta by Shevchuk
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Kiev
Legal_Standard: Risk of persecution must exist in every part of the home country
Application_Factor: Personalized threat, lack of systemic anti-Semitism, availability of state protection in Kiev
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed due to viable IFA in Kiev

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant alleged risk of abduction and extortion due to extended stay in Canada; officer failed to address these risks in PRRA assessment
Procedural_Issue: Officer did not address all risk factors presented by the applicant; decision found procedurally unfair
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Respondent argued insufficient evidence, but officer still had duty to assess all risks regardless of evidentiary support
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; original decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of PRRA application for redetermination by a different officer with opportunity for new submissions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unreasonableness and procedural fairness under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to consider all alleged risks, rendering the decision unreasonable and procedurally unfair
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer responsible for PRRA assessment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Senior Official in Regime with Human Rights Violations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Male applicant served as Lieutenant Colonel (rank 6 of 17) in the Iraqi army under Saddam Hussein's regime; Officer used military hierarchy charts and consulted War Crimes Unit to assess seniority.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of duty of fairness during assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants were given opportunity to respond; no deficiency noted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Position fell within top half of military hierarchy; decision was reasonable and transparent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Violation of human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with regime committing human rights violations
Crimes.Outcome: No violation found by reviewing body; application dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Male applicant’s role as senior military official in Saddam Hussein’s regime
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights standards
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Assessment by Immigration Officer with input from War Crimes Unit
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Regime engaged in human rights violations
Crimes.Credibility: Applicants had opportunity to respond; credibility not directly challenged
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed inadequate due to nature of regime

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant suffered from psoriasis after donating a kidney to her brother in Canada; faced hardship returning to Vietnam
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Procedural_Issue: Immigration officer made speculative assumptions without evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting assumptions about medical facilities in Vietnam
Decision_Outcome: Denial of humanitarian and compassionate grounds application
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review, invalidated the original decision
Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of application by another immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25(1)
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to unsupported assumptions about healthcare in Vietnam
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, re-evaluation assigned to another officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of cocaine possession with a maximum sentence of at least 10 years, triggering inadmissibility under IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness: lack of notice and opportunity to make submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer's Report did not allow applicant to respond or provide evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer's Report and s. 44(2) Referral quashed; Deportation Order invalidated
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of Officer's Report, referral, and deportation order
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Broad discretion exists but must be exercised fairly; failure to inform and hear the applicant breached fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purposes of trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether duty of fairness was breached in immigration proceedings
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of admissibility hearing outcomes
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for cocaine possession leading to 30-month sentence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer's Report and referral quashed; deportation order invalidated
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On immigration authorities to follow fair procedures
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 44(1) and s. 44(2) of IRPA require procedural fairness in reporting and referral
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of notice, inability to submit evidence, no copy of report provided
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction under Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA framework for inadmissibility and removal
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant not given opportunity to respond
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decisions and reconsideration with proper procedure
Crimes.Authority: Immigration officer, Minister's delegate, Federal Court on judicial review

Application_Facts: Applicant had temporary resident status in Australia, which may have expired before the RPD hearing
Residency_Compliance: Unclear compliance; status may have expired
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider the effective date for exclusion under Article 1E
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to determine timing and effect of residency status expiration
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee claim based on Article 1E exclusion
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for rehearing
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation and application of Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: RPD erred by not analyzing when the Applicant ceased to have rights and obligations equivalent to nationality in Australia
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board - Refugee Protection Division (IRB-RPD)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: El-Khader was physically present for 925 days out of the required 1,095 days within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge's decision to Federal Court; argument over use of quantitative vs. qualitative test
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documented residency to meet statutory threshold
Relief_Sought: Overturn Citizenship Judge's decision and grant citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's interpretation and application of residency requirement
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the quantitative physical presence test as per Pourghasemi; consistent with statutory interpretation principles

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of extortion due to civil war conditions; application lacked evidence of persecution or serious personal impact.
Procedural_Issue: Non-disclosure of UNHCR and UK Reports used in decision-making; failure to raise fear of extortion during interviews or updates.
Evidence_Used: UNHCR Report, UK Country Information Report
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting persecution or serious personal impact from civil war; insufficient advancement of extortion claim.
Credibility_Assessment: Fear of extortion not adequately substantiated or advanced by applicant.
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no breach of procedural fairness found
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness, reasonableness standard under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Documents relied upon were not novel or significant enough to require disclosure; applicant did not sufficiently advance the extortion claim during the process.

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed his immigration consultant was incompetent, leading to failure of PRRA application
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of natural justice due to incompetent counsel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided by applicant to prove incompetence or prejudice
Legal_Standard_Applied: Breach of natural justice occurs if incompetence completely denies the applicant a hearing; otherwise, extraordinary circumstances with specific evidence required
Decision_Rationale: No substantial proof of incompetence or prejudice; no evidentiary basis for breach of natural justice

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 96-97
Application_Facts: Mr. Lozano's testimony contained inconsistencies due to untreated bipolar disorder
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider medical evidence affecting credibility
Evidence_Used: Testimony, Medical Evidence of Bipolar Disorder
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not adequately consider medical evidence regarding mental health
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent testimony dismissed without proper consideration of mental health impact
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected based on credibility
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to account for mental health condition in assessing credibility

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Mahjoub's release can be modified to neutralize threat to national security or safety of any person
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Mahjoub has repeatedly disavowed Islamic extremism; no evidence of contact with terrorists since 2000
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Security certificate alleging ties to terrorist organizations
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Length of detention, compliance with conditions, lack of new evidence, health deterioration
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether release under conditions would be injurious to national security or endanger any person
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Ministers' claims without new supporting evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation in obtaining travel documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in conduct contrary to a court order
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention review and modification of release conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can Mr. Mahjoub be released under less stringent conditions without posing a threat?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No new threat-related activities; health issues and isolation noted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to justify continued detention
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Compliance with prior conditions and willingness to accept GPS monitoring
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for less restrictive conditions due to prolonged detention and health concerns
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Agreed to GPS and modified supervision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Threatening the security of Canada through association with terrorist groups
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged ties to Egyptian Islamic terrorist organizations
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat to national security if released without controls
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Diminished over time due to long detention and disengagement
Crimes.Organization_Involved: Egyptian Islamic Jihad or related entities
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged involvement based on security certificate
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Classified evidence presented by CSIS; no recent corroboration
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of updated intelligence to support ongoing high threat level
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible past concern but diminished current risk

Crimes.Crime_Name: Participating in activities of a terrorist group
Crimes.Application_Facts: Security certificate issued based on alleged participation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to immigration control due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of security certificate and access to evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration and security
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of recent evidence demonstrating active participation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Past allegations not currently substantiated
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Threat reduced over time; conditions can mitigate residual risk
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Detention under security certificate for alleged terrorist links
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential danger if released without safeguards
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Reduced due to prolonged detention and behavioral compliance
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged based on intelligence, not criminal conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Based on classified intelligence; limited disclosure
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on stale intelligence without renewal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns mitigated by time and behavior
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable belief based on balance of probabilities

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a weapon or explosive substance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can conditions be adjusted to allow less restrictive supervision without compromising security?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of weapon possession; focus on general threat level
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown/Minister to justify continued strict detention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Health deterioration, social isolation, lack of live-in supervisor
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Willingness to accept GPS and restricted movement

Violation_Type: Failure to apply qualitative residency test
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirements under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Mr. Dedaj met the 1,095-day physical presence requirement but had post-application ties to the U.S.
Residency_Compliance: Met quantitative physical presence; qualitative assessment not properly applied
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to consider qualitative factors in residency determination
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess qualitative factors from Koo case
Decision_Outcome: Original application dismissed due to perceived insufficient residency
Remedy_Sought: Order for new citizenship judge to reassess using both quantitative and qualitative tests
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative 1,095-day rule and qualitative residency test from Koo
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred in law by not applying the qualitative test for residency despite meeting physical presence requirements

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - ss. 34(1)
Application_Facts: Ms. Lewis overstayed her visitor's visa and remained in Canada without legal status; removal date passed while humanitarian and compassionate application was pending.
Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with conditions of stay
Procedural_Issue: Application for deferral of removal denied; judicial review sought after removal date passed
Evidence_Used: Visa expiration date, CBSA records, pending H&C application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness doctrine in administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Removal date has passed, rendering the issue moot despite unresolved permanent residency application
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division, Immigration Appeal Division, Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - ss. 34(1)
Application_Facts: Ms. Lewis did not extend her visa after expiry, leading to an exclusion order and removal proceedings; PRRA and deferral requests denied
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review sought after denial of deferral; case deemed moot due to passed removal date
Evidence_Used: Visa expiration, exclusion order, PRRA denial, H&C application status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness doctrine in administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Removal date passed before judicial review, making the matter moot regardless of pending H&C application

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in Turkey based on ethnicity, religion, and political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to meaningfully consider psychological report in credibility assessment
Evidence_Used: Dr. Devins' psychological report diagnosing chronic posttraumatic stress disorder
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of discussion on relevance of PTSD diagnosis to credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant's credibility but did not adequately address impact of mental health condition
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed claim primarily due to credibility concerns
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard for credibility findings
Decision_Rationale: Board's failure to analyze medical evidence affecting credibility was clearly unreasonable

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Father's death; family seeking permanent residence; child's best interests central to H&C application; return to Guyana would impact child
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with immigration status prior to refusal
Procedural_Issue: Officer applied incorrect legal test by requiring 'unusual and undeserved' or 'disproportionate' hardship instead of treating best interests of the child as a primary consideration
Evidence_Used: Impact of father's death, conditions in Guyana, child's ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to adequately consider evidence regarding child's best interests
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residence application based on insufficient H&C grounds
Relief_Sought: Allowance of permanent residence application on H&C grounds
Remedy_Sought: Remission of case to a different decision-maker for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child must be a primary consideration in H&C applications
Decision_Rationale: Officer unreasonably elevated the threshold for hardship; failed to properly apply the best interests of the child as required by law
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer at Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Mr. Tumarkin’s admissibility is under investigation, affecting the family's applications. No evidence shows refusal or unreasonable delay beyond average processing times.
Procedural_Issue: Splitting files is discretionary, not a right.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence shows refusal or unreasonable delay beyond average processing times.
Decision_Outcome: No writ of mandamus will be issued
Outcome: Application dismissed; no mandamus granted; applicants can reapply if needed.
Relief_Sought: Writ of mandamus to expedite and split citizenship applications
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandamus applies if there is a public legal duty, clear right to performance, no other adequate remedy, and practical value.
Decision_Rationale: Delays are within reasonable bounds and splitting files is discretionary.

Legal_Issue: Unreasonable delay in processing citizenship applications
Evidence_Assessment: Processing times are within average limits; CBSA investigating Mr. Tumarkin's admissibility due to potential fraud charges in Russia.
Decision_Outcome: No writ of mandamus will be issued
Legal_Rule: Mandamus requires a public legal duty, clear right to performance, no other adequate remedy, and practical value. Splitting files is discretionary.
Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived undue delay and request to split family applications
Key_Evidence_Considered: Potential fraud charges in Russia, residency questions, average processing times
Legal_Framework: Mandamus principles, legislative provisions on immigration
Evidence_Type: Alleged criminal charges in Russia, residency information
Remedy_Requested: Expedited processing and splitting of applications via mandamus
Outcome: Application dismissed; applicants can reapply if circumstances change

Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa in Canada
Procedural_Issue: RAD applied incorrect standard of review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether RAD has authority to apply reasonableness standard
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by RPD and upheld by RAD
Outcome: RAD decision set aside, case remanded
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by RAD using correct standard
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Decision_Rationale: RAD is an appellate body and must apply palpable and overriding error or hybrid standard

Victim_Status: Individual at risk due to family wealth and perceived activism
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant credible but denied claim on other grounds

Key_Evidence_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Dispute_Type: Standard of review in refugee appeals
Consequences_of_Action: RAD decision set aside, remanded for redetermination

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on extortion risk
Legal_Issue: Appropriate standard of review for RAD
Evidence_Assessment: Fear based on family wealth and conflict environment
Decision_Outcome: Claim denied by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate well-founded fear
Legal_Rule: RAD must apply palpable and overriding error standard
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of extortion and forced enlistment in Syria
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached due to procedural error

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving nondisclosure of activities
Legal_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove eligibility for protection
Legal_Rule: RAD must substitute its decision unless bound by credibility findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived activism and fundraising
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided due to procedural error
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their visa and applied for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds, citing family reunification and moral support.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants were temporary residents who remained in Canada after their visa expired
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of H&C application within Canadian jurisdiction despite lack of status
Crimes.Evidence_Used: General letter from son emphasizing importance of family unity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of concrete evidence demonstrating unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims based on parental love deemed insufficient to establish significant hardship
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship if required to apply from abroad
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded that applicants failed to demonstrate sufficient hardship or integration to justify H&C relief

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 30(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada without legal status and sought permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds, primarily based on family ties.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants were individuals without valid immigration status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No lawful status; residing in Canada without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the assessment of child's best interests and overall reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Consideration of H&C claims by individuals without status residing in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Used: General letter regarding family unity; no documentation of integration or hardship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of significant hardship, deep roots, or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not substantiated with objective evidence beyond emotional bonds
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of the immigration officer’s decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Demonstration of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship upon departure
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably determined that applicants did not meet the threshold for H&C relief due to lack of compelling evidence

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is an elderly woman who overstayed her visa and sought permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to her daughter's disability and inability to return to Guatemala.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for humanitarian and compassionate consideration under subsection 25(1)
Evidence_Used: Potential reliance on Canadian social services
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided regarding daughter's condition and lack of support from other relatives
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Burden on Canadian services outweighed compassionate considerations; insufficient evidence of hardship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada as required by the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate exemption
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officer's refusal under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence supporting hardship claim and potential burden on social services
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet procedural requirement to apply from outside Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of exemption request under subsection 25(1)

Application_Facts: Applicants were denied citizenship due to insufficient physical presence; applicants were abroad during assessment period
Residency_Compliance: Not met – insufficient physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to review residency questionnaires; lack of fair hearing
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not consider submitted questionnaires
Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a different citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) residency requirement; principles of procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Applicants failed to meet residency requirement; judge erred in not providing fair opportunity to present case
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court Trial Division

Violation_Type: Excessive demand on health or social services
Application_Facts: Medical narrative focused primarily on educational expenses without considering family support or service availability
Procedural_Issue: Failure to obtain necessary information
Defective medical opinion
Evidence_Used: Educational and social service cost assessments
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of comprehensive assessment of all relevant factors
Overreliance on educational costs
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing by a different visa officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Excessive demand on health or social services under s. 19(1)(a)(ii)
Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable application of statutory test due to incomplete information and narrow focus on educational costs

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent statements, lack of credible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(2) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Revocation of passport and five-year ban
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No obligation to provide translation services; non-disclosure of irrelevant information
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Draft letters (deemed not indicative of bias)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, absence of bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Passport revocation and five-year ban upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in passport use and application

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants facilitated fraud by impostors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Payment records, false applications, investigation findings
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(2) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Revocation due to allowing impostors to use passports
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Payment of $10,000 per impostor, complicity in fraud
Crimes.Application_Error: Provided false information in replacement applications
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, absence of bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Unauthorized use of passport by impostors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing false information in support of a passport application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent statements, failure to respond to inquiries
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(2) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in passport application process

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Administrative Law
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants allowed misuse of passports
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No procedural breach; evidence supported conclusion
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, absence of bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in immigration and passport context

Legal_Issue: Appropriate penalty for contempt due to non-compliance with court order
Procedural_Stage: Sentencing after guilty plea to contempt
Evidence_Assessment: Defendant knowingly continued using trademark despite injunction and warnings
Decision_Outcome: Solicitor-client costs ($62,000), fine ($50,000 reducible to $10,000 if paid within 30 days), suspended 14-day imprisonment for director
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove contempt by clear and convincing evidence
Legal_Rule: Contempt penalties may include fines, imprisonment, or costs; deliberate defiance is aggravating, first offense and guilty plea are mitigating
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of permanent injunction prohibiting trademark infringement
Outcome_on_Merits: Contempt established; significant penalties imposed with conditional reduction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of non-compliance (over one year), lack of apology, prior settlement offers, defendant’s awareness of injunction
Defendant_Response: Pleaded guilty to contempt, delayed compliance, no apology
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of injunction, correspondence, settlement offers, admission of violation
Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of court order, financial penalties, potential imprisonment
Outcome: Financial penalties ordered with conditional reduction for prompt payment; suspended sentence for non-compliance

Dispute_Type: Credibility dispute, Sur place refugee claim
Legal_Issue: Credibility findings, Consideration of sur place claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence found implausible regarding relationship, escape, and medical treatment
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, Medical records, Evidence of activism
Legal_Provision: Section 97 or 98 of IRPA (refugee protection), Section 101(1)(a) or (f) - well-founded fear of persecution
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution for homosexuality, Subsequent claim as a gay rights activist in Canada (sur place)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence supporting relationship, escape, medical treatment, and insufficient proof of activism risking persecution
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Application_Error: Failure to raise or substantiate sur place claim explicitly, Implausibility in key narrative elements
Legal_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of persecution, Plausibility and consistency of testimony
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of refugee claim, No error found by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency requirements under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s.28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Abrams did not request an adjournment for legal representation nor claimed unfairness due to lack of counsel. The Board provided a detailed decision considering humanitarian and compassionate factors.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged denial of right to counsel and fair hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Humanitarian and compassionate factors considered by the Board
Crimes.Outcome: Abrams remained inadmissible and subject to removal
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness or bias; no formal request for adjournment or counsel made

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on illegal entry into the U.S.
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Denial of right to counsel and fair hearing
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian administrative law, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony and record of proceedings before Immigration Appeal Board
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions of IRPA regarding inadmissibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Attempted illegal entry into the United States
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No formal request for adjournment despite absence of counsel
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to formally request adjournment or object to proceeding without counsel
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Fair hearing under principles of natural justice
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Right to fair hearing and right to counsel
Crimes.Application_Factor: Complexity of case and need for legal representation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed application for judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminality leading to inadmissibility under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to foreign criminal convictions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Abrams was denied a fair hearing or right to counsel
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Board decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board considered criminal history and residency violations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Natural justice requires fair hearing; no automatic right to counsel unless requested
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged violation of natural justice during appeal hearing
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Foreign criminal convictions and failure to meet residency obligations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and principles of administrative fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not request adjournment or indicate unpreparedness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer's conclusion of material misrepresentation was reasonable
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 40 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Dhatt disclosed the adoption deed from the start; no concealment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of a fraudulent birth certificate
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Disclosure of adoption; no intent to mislead
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider full context of disclosure
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: The fact that adoption was disclosed and not concealed
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent to induce error in immigration administration

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer's conclusion of material misrepresentation via fraudulent document was reasonable
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 40 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Dhatt disclosed adoption; no intent to mislead Canadian authorities
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Procurement and submission of a fraudulent birth certificate
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Honest belief and disclosure of adoption; no concealment
Crimes.Application_Error: Overlooking disclosure and context of document use
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Adoption deed disclosed from the beginning
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Material and intentional misrepresentation under Section 40
Crimes.Application_Factor: Potential to induce error despite disclosure
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Fraudulent birth certificate obtained and submitted

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Public Service Appeal Board Decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the second selection process was a new process or a corrective measure; whether the Commission had authority to conduct a new selection process
Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act (PSEA), subsections 21(2), 21(3), and section 10
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review following dismissal of appeal by the Public Service Appeal Board
Evidence_Assessment: Commission's letter stating the nature of the new competition
Decision_Outcome: Appeal Board's decision upheld; judicial review application dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error by the Appeal Board
Legal_Rule: PSEA allows but does not require corrective measures under subsection 21(3); subsection 21(2) mandates revocation of appointments on successful appeal; merit-based selection under section 10
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Appeal Board in characterizing the second selection process as entirely new rather than a corrective measure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commission's letter directing a new competition with updated qualifications
Defendant_Response: Commission acted within its authority under PSEA to direct a new selection process
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Appeal Board decision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Prohibition on granting citizenship due to criminal conviction under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Does subsection 5(4) of the Citizenship Act prevail over paragraph 22(2)(a)?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's criminal conviction for drug trafficking within three years of application
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility despite disqualification
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – based on legal interpretation, not witness credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Generalia specialibus non derogant – specific provisions override general ones
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that discretion under subsection 5(4) should allow citizenship
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction record and timing relative to citizenship application
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No direct response; decision based on statutory bar
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Grant of citizenship through discretionary authority

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether discretion under 5(4) was properly considered
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship denied due to statutory bar
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug trafficking within three years of application
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Serious criminality under immigration and citizenship law
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Public safety and integrity of citizenship regime
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Citizenship Act and principles of statutory interpretation

Legal_Issue: Changed circumstances and compelling reasons for persecution
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed due to ceased need for protection

Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to contradictions in testimony regarding payments, police complaints, and selling items
Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to discrepancies in payments and confusion about police interactions
Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Evidence_Type: Testimony about payments and selling items
Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to inconsistent statements about payments and police complaints
Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Application_Facts: Applicant provided contradictory testimony
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent statements about payments, police complaints, and activities
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment by Refugee Protection Division
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions and implausibilities in testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible based on cumulative contradictions
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question or reversal of decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Panel provided clear reasons based on contradictions in testimony

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer breached the duty of fairness or erred in law in denying exemption under s. 114(2)
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence that marriage was genuine and that return to Northern Ireland posed risks
Evidence_Type: Interview records, risk-related documents, marriage evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of sufficient evidence supporting genuine marriage and personal risk
Decision_Maker: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Assessment_Standard: Duty of fairness; minimal procedural obligations
Legal_Standard: Error in law, bad faith, improper principles

Legal_Issue: Was the visa officer's decision to deny permanent residence reasonable under subsection 75(2) of the Regulations?
Governing_Law: subsection 75(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Officer focused excessively on minor details in the employment letter; failed to adequately assess applicant's duties against NOC requirements
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate eligibility for permanent residence
Credibility_Factor: Perceived insufficient evidence of job duties matching NOC codes
Legal_Rule: Visa officers' decisions are reviewed for reasonableness, requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Factual errors and lack of transparency in decision-making
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa officer's decision lacked clarity and intelligible reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Employment letter, NOC requirements, description of job duties
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Defendant_Response: Denial based on insufficient demonstration of qualifying work experience
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (employment letter), statutory classification (NOC code)
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision and re-determination by a different visa officer
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision quashed; matter remanded for re-assessment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in terrorism, systematic or gross human rights violations, genocide, war crimes, or crimes against humanity
National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with genocidal regime
Threat_Assessment: Presumption of complicity based on position
Nature_of_Acts: Genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity
Admission_or_Involvement: Presumed involvement due to official status
Evidence_Credibility: Credible public record of regime’s actions
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of individual exculpatory evidence considered
Credibility_Assessment: Not assessed individually due to irrebuttable presumption
Standard_of_Proof: Presumption without need for individual proof
Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 35(1)(b)
Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 16
Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada, denial of refugee protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility for violating human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Judicial review challenging constitutionality of inadmissibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Senior official in regime committing genocide
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Institutional_Action: Canada Border Services Agency determination upheld
Government_Body_or_Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Protected_Group: Victims of genocide and crimes against humanity
State_Protection_Assessment: Regime failed to protect its citizens
Risk_Factor: High risk of persecution and harm due to regime actions
Credibility: Claimant's lack of individual defense permitted
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate protection by Rwandan government during genocide
Risk_Nature: Systematic extermination based on ethnic identity
Perpetrator_Entity: Government of Rwanda and affiliated forces

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper exclusion under s. 114(2) due to 'organized plan' and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentations noted but humanitarian factors outweighed
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's jurisdictional error in applying rigid guidelines
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Holistic evaluation of humanitarian and compassionate factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Plaintiffs' establishment in Canada, family ties, and integration
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory discretion under s. 114(2) cannot be unduly restricted by guidelines
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Entitled to new hearing before different officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or visa documentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Lawfulness of excluding applicants based on 'organized plan'
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of entry method and residency establishment
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Truthfulness of entry claims and integration in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Ministerial guidelines cannot override statutory discretion
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Reliance on 'organized plan' exclusion in guidelines

Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs overstayed visas and applied under H&C program
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant past status, compliant present integration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Generally credible despite initial violations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper denial based on 'organized plan' and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentation found but mitigated by humanitarian factors
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Establishment in Canada and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Jurisdictional error in rigid guideline application
Crimes.Application_Error: Denial based solely on 'organized plan' without H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Integration, employment, family ties in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory discretion prevails over restrictive guidelines
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior misrepresentation and mode of entry

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to depart after visa expiration
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs remained beyond authorized stay and applied for permanent residency
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged participation in organized entry scheme
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible claimants despite immigration violations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Guidelines must not override statutory intent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings?
Outcome: The Member erred by not considering refugee hearings in assessing flight risk. Case remitted for redetermination.
Application_Error: Failure to consider relevance of refugee hearings in flight risk assessment
Legal_Standard: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention

Application_Facts: Applicants wanted in China for fraud, seeking refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider ongoing proceedings in detention decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider active refugee claims as a factor in flight risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention
Decision_Rationale: Focus on removal likelihood without considering refugee hearings was unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings as part of the flight risk analysis?
Evidence_Assessment: Member focused solely on removal likelihood
Legal_Rule: ID must assess flight risk and alternatives to detention, including upcoming proceedings
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous omission of relevant proceedings in flight risk analysis
Legal_Framework: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Legal_Provision: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Potential breach in assessment of personalized risk
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Possibly found due to mischaracterization of risk

Legal_Provision: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Non-compliance with immigration status after fleeing persecution
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Mexico due to threats
Procedural_Issue: Board's failure to properly assess risk
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board dismissed personalized nature despite credible evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk under s. 97
Decision_Rationale: Risk was particularized, not generalized

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on criminal victimization
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Insufficient reasoning on personalization of risk

Legal_Issue: Whether the registrant proved use of the VISIBLE YOUTH trademark during the relevant period
Evidence_Assessment: Initial finding of insufficient evidence; new affidavits and exhibits later demonstrated sufficient use
Burden_of_Proof: Registrant must show prima facie evidence of use
Credibility_Factor: Bona fide sale sufficient to establish use
Legal_Rule: A single bona fide sale constitutes use under section 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Outcome_on_Merits: Registration upheld due to proof of use prior to assignment in August 2001
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sales records, invoices, product images bearing the mark
Defendant_Response: Presented new affidavits and exhibits demonstrating use
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (invoices, sales records, product images)
